countries.name: Australia
summary: Australians are very straightforward and do not need a personal relationship to do business.
They are modest and appreciate modesty in their colleagues.
You’re always welcome to give your opinion, regardless of age and hierarchy.
organisational: Australians are very straightforward and do not need a personal relationship to do business.
Final decisions might take longer since team members are often consulted before the manager makes a decision.
Patience is very much appreciated.
meetings: Tardiness reflects badly in a professional setting. Be one time or even a few minutes early.
Meetings should follow the agenda, however, expect the first meetings to primarily focus on getting to know each other and establishing trustworthiness.
You’re always welcome to give your opinion, regardless of age and hierarchy.
Australians find debates entertaining and will initiate them by making provocative statements, it is best to respond to them with humour.
social: Australians are not very formal, so expect a casual and relaxed greeting.
Table manners are the same as in Europe.
In a pub, each person is expected to pay for a round of drinks, avoiding your turn will create a bad impression.
Avoid the topic of religion, politics and sex, unless your Australian team member brings it up.

countries.name: Brazil
summary: Brazilians do business with people, not with companies. Put time and effort into personal relations.
Brazilians are flexible with time, it is advisable to be on time and not to show frustration or impatience with delays.
Lots of physical contact whilst talking is common.
organisational: The official language is Portuguese, present documents in Portuguese and English.
Brazil has a vertical hierarchical business structure, the highest-ranking member will make the decision.
Brazilians do business with people, not with companies. Put time and effort into personal relations.
meetings: Brazilians are flexible with time, it is advisable to be on time and not to show frustration or impatience with delays.
First contact will be more successful when introduced by a mutual acquaintance.
When doing a presentation, keep it short, and expect lots of interruptions and questions.
social: During a conversation, a lot of touching of the arms and back is common.
Avoid the topics of politics, poverty, religion and Argentina.
Openness and friendliness are expected.
The line between personal and professional relations is blurry.
When dining, whoever invited pays, however, the other party is expected to offer to pay.

countries.name: Canada
summary: Originally hierarchical.
Be 5 to 10 min early to meetings, punctuality is highly valued.
Canadians are politically correct and diplomatic.
organisational: Canada is traditionally hierarchical, however, flattened hierarchy is gaining ground.
Managers are in charge of final decisions.
Personal relationship is not necessary when doing business.
Canada is bilingual in French and English.
It is considered rude to speak in a foreign language in the presence of other people who do not understand what is being said.
meetings: Be 5 to 10 min early to meetings, punctuality is highly valued.
Meetings tend to be formal.
Presentations should be short and clear, it is important to show facts and figures.
Communication is indirect, Canadians are politically correct.
social: Dress code is conservative, well-dressed appearance.
During lunches and dinners, talk is more formal, but business can still be done.
Do not start eating before everyone at the table has been served.
Canadians feel more comfortable talking when they can look you in the eyes.
Popular small talk topic is sports: hockey, football, baseball etc.

countries.name: China
summary: Strong focus on respect and hierarchy.
Business meals and entertainment as a way of relationship building.
Watch out for Chinese regulations, such as the ban on gift-giving.
organisational: Workplaces in China are definitively hierarchical based on age and position, and everyone has a distinct place and role within their company.
Chinese business is very relationship based. Take time to build up a good connection with your business partners.
The ‘996’ work schedule (working 6 days a week from 9am to 9pm) is an indication of a fierce working culture at Chinese tech companies. It is however more regulated nowadays.
China’s business language is Mandarin; taking an interpreter to a business meeting is advised
meetings: People enter a meeting in order of importance, the highest-ranking person arriving first, and so on. The same goes for introductions.
Regarding titles of courtesy, most people should be addressed with a title followed by their last name.
Make sure that you are punctual. If you are late, be sure to offer an apology for your tardiness. Allow a 10-minute interval for others to arrive.

Business cards should be treated with respect, in Chinese culture it is indicative of the respect you will show the individual in business. Either use both hands or the right hand alone to receive a business car. Treat them as if they are gifts. A Chinese translation on one side will be appreciated.
Conservative suits. Bright colours of any kind are considered inadequate.
Chinese colleagues may applaud when you are introduced as a way of greeting you and showing approval. If so, it is appropriate to applaud back.
You are expected to greet everyone in the room individually, even if the group is large.
Allow a few moments of social conversation to pass before mentioning business.
Traditionally, the host will give a quick speech greeting everyone before discussing the topic of business.
social: Handshakes are the standard, casual greeting. The grip tends to be lighter than the Western handshake and is also sustained for longer.
Business dinners and entertainment play a central role in conducting business in China and are part of creating a harmonious relationship.
If you are invited to a business meal, wait to be seated, as there is a seating protocol based on hierarchy.
Do not discuss business during the meal, unless the host brings it up.
Don’t give gifts, official policy considers it to be bribery and therefore illegal.

countries.name: France
summary: French is the official and preferred language.
Strong separation between work and personal life.
Plan meetings at least two weeks in advance.
organisational: No work on sundays (by law)
Organization typically hierarchical and centralized. Decisions are made at the top of the company. The boss of the company will be authoritative.
The typical working week in France is 35 hours.
Hard work is admired, but generally the French frown upon workaholism.
meetings: Meetings are usually arranged well in advance, with plenty of forewarning for all parties; around two weeks’ notice is expected.
Stay focused on the business reason for the meeting, avoid small talk and don’t stray into questions or revelations about private life
Formal attire, suit and tie for men,  smart dress pants or dresses for women.
social: Greetings: Never hug a French person to say hi. They don’t hug, they’ll just lean in and give you a cheek tap on either side to greet you, say hi and bye. Cheek-kisses, known as “la bise”.
Politeness: There’s always a merci or s’il vous plait tacked on to any interaction at a store and people are addressed as madame or monsieur.
Most French do not like to discuss business during dinner. Dinner is considered to be more of a social occasion and a time to enjoy the food, drinks and discussions.

countries.name: Germany
summary: Germans are very formal, heavily regulated and extremely bureaucratic.
Punctuality is extremely important.
Germans are direct to the point of bluntness.
organisational: Germany is heavily regulated and extremely bureaucratic.
A strict vertical hierarchy is established and respected, and the decision-making process is held at the top of the company.
The Germans respect authority and subordinates rarely contradict or criticize their superiors publicly.
Final decisions are translated into rigorous, comprehensive action steps that you can expect will be carried out to the letter.

Germans like working in teams and collaborate quite well across hierarchical lines. The communication within the team is usually quite collegial. Praise should be given to the entire group as well as to individuals.
Be careful not to be seen to be cutting corners or compromising rules and regulations when communicating with your German colleagues.
meetings: Meetings are generally formal.
Appointments are mandatory and should be made 1 to 2 weeks in advance.
Punctuality is extremely important, and arriving at a meeting 15 minutes early is well thought of.
In case of any delay, it is imperative to inform your colleagues in advance.
Meetings adhere to strict agendas, including starting and ending times.
It is considered extremely rude to cancel a meeting last minute.
Business dress is understated, formal and conservative. Men should wear dark-coloured, conservative business suits. Women should wear either dark business suits or conservative dresses.
social: Gift-giving is uncommon in business meetings. If you’re visiting and considering a gift choose one that is small and of good quality, but not overly expensive.
When invited to a German home, it is appropriate to bring a gift of flowers, wine, chocolates or a small gift that represents your home country or region.
As a group, Germans are suspicious of hyperbole, promises that sound too good to be true, or displays of emotion.
Germans will be direct to the point of bluntness.

countries.name: India
summary: Relationship-based business culture, use third-party introductions.
Focus on respect and hierarchy.
Indians tend to avoid confrontation and disagreements.
organisational: Workplaces in India are hierarchical, based on age and position.
There is an intention to complete the work on time; however they often don’t give early warning of problems. It’s better to check-up how the work is going and will it be ready on time.
Highest-ranking person makes the final decisions.
meetings: People enter a meeting in order of importance, with the highest-ranking person arriving first and so on. The same goes for introductions.
Treat business cards with respect. Accept and give them with two hands or your right hand, watch it before carefully putting it away.
Take time to get to know your business partner, allowing for a casual conversation to begin a meeting.
Expect some meetings or discussions to be conducted over dinner or drinks.
Highest-ranking person makes the final decisions, if that person is not present there are more introductory talks.
Indian people are flexible when it comes to punctuality. Arriving at a meeting 15 minutes after the official starting time is not rare
social: The Indian dress-code is relatively casual.
Very relationship-based, third-party introductions are almost a necessity as Indians prefer to work with those whom they know and trust.
It may be difficult to enter a friendly relationship with a person, but once entered, friends are treated as family.
In social situations among themselves, Indians are personal and informal.
Indians are taught to minimize conflict and strive for harmony, they may stall or avoid you to eliminate direct confrontation.

countries.name: Indonesia
summary: Do not interrupt an Indonesian.
Hierarchical based on age and position.
Avoid direct confrontation.
organisational: Hierarchical based on age and position.
Leadership is paternalistic and the oldest person usually leads discussion
meetings: Arrive on time but consider that your Indonesian counterpart may be late to a meeting.
Consensus is sought from everyone before a decision is made in order to maintain harmony.
Greet everyone in the room individually with a handshake.
Greet people in order of their seniority in any professional setting
Receive and present business cards with respect. Give and take them with both hands, inspect it for a moment before putting it away.
First meetings are mainly for getting to know each other, business might not even be discussed.
social: Do not interrupt an Indonesian. They will usually give you plenty of room to speak and often show a great amount of respect during conversation.
Boisterous behaviour is seen negatively.
Show compassion and be personable, but do not be confrontational or let emotion get in the way of negotiations.
Wear suits or traditional shirts. Wearing a batik fabric is likely to be met with appreciation.

countries.name: Italy
summary: Deep personal relationships.
Focus on hierarchy.
Meetings mainly for discussing and exchange of ideas.
organisational: Hierarchy is important in Italian business culture. Status is often based on  age and position.

Italians like to be flexible about business. It is common for people to bend rules and put different interpretations on regulations in order to get around business constraints. Mainly in bureaucratic gray areas.
Verbal agreements are generally adhered to on the basis of trust – breaking them can jeopardise business relationships.
meetings: Be punctual to give a good impression, but do not always expect your Italian counterpart to do the same as timekeeping is looser.
Everyone – including those who hold lower statuses – is usually given the opportunity to speak during meetings
Credit for decisions is almost always given to the person of the highest status.
Decisions are not always reached during meetings as they often serve the purpose of exchanging ideas, hashing out details and hearing the perspectives of all who are involved.
social: Expect personal questions about your family and personal life.
Italians can appear overly expressive. After heated arguments they quickly revert to being friendly and jovial.
Italians invest much time and effort in their relationships and getting to know those whom they work with.
Gift giving is not particularly common. When invited for a family lunch or dinner you can give small gifts to thank them for their hospitality.

countries.name: Japan
summary: Japanese companies have strong hierarchical structures, it is expected that subordinates respect their superiors.
Respect is shown by working hard, being on time and being polite. Bowing is a part of this as well, but if you are not well versed in the details you can better stick to a respectful handshake.
The country is more conservative then many Western countries, this can be taken account in how you dress.
organisational: Any rules/laws should always be obeyed.
Punctuality is very important.
Long work hours are the norm, and in many companies you are expected not to leave before your supervisor does.
Related to the previous point, taking paid leave can be looked down upon.
Business cards are seen as an extension of the person themselves so receive and treat them respectfully.
meetings: People may wear surgical masks if they are not feeling well to avoid spreading any sickness.
Directness is not always appreciated, neither is being overly opinionated.
Bare shoulders are seen as provocative, it may be better to cover up for any physical or video meetings.
Blowing your nose in public is no appreciated.
social: Respect is an essential part of any social interaction, when in doubt be respectful.
Work dinners are very normal in Japan, these are seen as essential part of work. Missing them may be seen as disrespectful.
Initially it may be difficult to form a closer bond with your Japanese colleagues as they can be quite reserved.
Privacy is highly valued, be careful with asking questions related to someones private life.

countries.name: Mexico
summary: Mexicans are status-conscious.
Strong and deep relationships are fundamental to business agreements.
Meetings may stray from the proposed agenda.
organisational: Hierarchical based on seniority
Business is very relationship-based, and a good or bad impression may override business objectives.
meetings: Arrange meetings in advance and confirm the date and time several times in advance. Doing so conveys your eagerness to meet.
Start and finishing times are usually set as estimates. Arrive on time but expect that your Mexican counterpart may not be as punctual.
Allow some time for small talk to precede any serious discussion of business. If it is the first time parties have met, this initial acquaintance may consume the whole meeting.
Meetings may not always follow the proposed agenda systematically. The outline of the meeting usually serves as a rough guideline while topics and issues may be addressed as they are mentioned.
Small conversations may start while others are talking.
People may become quite passionate and emotional during meetings.
social: Mexicans are status conscious. Book engagements in settings that are reflective of one’s position and status.
Do not address someone by their first name until they have invited you to do so.
In order to deepen a relationship, try to be as talkative and transparent with them as possible.
Try and present yourself as personably as possible. Mexicans tend to warm to working with individuals rather than ‘representatives’ of businesses.

countries.name: Netherlands
summary: Punctuality is important. If you are running late, call your team members to let them know and give them the reason why you’re being late.
Business relationships are formal. Business is strictly professional and does not hold a relation to one’s personal life.
Inspired by “the Polder Model” - the Dutch have a slow decision-making process where all parties have to be heard, and everyone is entitled to an opinion.
organisational: Business relationships are formal. Business is strictly professional and does not hold a relation to one’s personal life.
In the Netherlands, hierarchy exists to serve organisational effectiveness. Managers are not necessarily seen as superiors, but rather as employees with different responsibilities.
Inspired by “the Polder Model” - the Dutch have a slow decision-making process where all parties have to be heard, and everyone is entitled to an opinion.
meetings: Punctuality is important. If you are running late, call your team members to let them know and give them the reason why you’re being late.
A small amount of small talk may begin the meeting, but expect the Dutch to turn to business very quickly.
The Dutch are very direct, do not take offence to this.
When entering a meeting room with new people, shake everyone's hand and introduce yourself with your first name.
social: The Dutch sometimes prefer a lunch meeting as opposed to meetings in the office, since lunch is a necessity anyway.
After-hours drinks are not appropriate for detailed discussions, since the Dutch want to go home. It is a nice way to build a personal connection with your colleagues.
Taking colleagues out for dinner is a private event, and will therefore rarely happen in Dutch business culture.

countries.name: Russia
summary: Power is emphasized and used.
Make appointments well in advance
Strongly hierarchical with well defined task mandates.
organisational: Strong hierarchy at all levels. There are clear mandates for all tasks.
A contract is not necessarily thought of as constantly binding unless it continues to be a mutually beneficial agreement for both parties.
Visible demonstrations of status.
Power is emphasized and used.
meetings: You should make appointments well in advance and arrive punctually.
Meetings may be canceled on short notice.
Be patient and expect meetings to run for a longer duration than scheduled.
There may be multiple interruptions to the flow of the meeting as people follow different tangents and discussions.
Follow up meetings with an email clarifying what you have understood to take place.
Negotiations may take long as Russians tend to patiently wait out deadlocks.
social: Russians are quite status conscious.
Talk to them as equals and do not come across as condescending.
Going for drinks is a popular way to build relationships.
Always dress formally for business occasions.

countries.name: South Korea
summary: In Korean culture it is very important to ensure harmony. This may mean that a colleague will prefer not to mention some bad news in order to preserve the harmony.
Koreans value respect towards superiors. This may pertain to a direct supervisor within your organisation or simply someone who is older.
In general it is better to follow the lead of your Korean colleagues, instead of trying to initiate a lot of conversation and interaction yourself. At least until you are more comfortable as a group.
organisational: Korea, similar to other Asian countries, often has a strong hierarchical structure in their companies. It is important to not publicly criticize a supervisor.
Employees are expected to work hard, and the work/life balance of an average Korean is more favored towards the former.
In business Koreans place quite some value on having a good relationship with their business partners.
The business Korean world is still quite dominated by men, and women may be expected to behave more feminine then in a average Western country.
meetings: Bare shoulders are seen as provocative, it may be better to cover up for any physical or video meetings.
Koreans may wear masks due to not feeling well or due to bad air quality.
Don't sign your name with a red pen, as this is associated with death.

Koreans are respectful in their language as well, if in doubt it is best to address your colleagues by their last name (which is the first part of their Korean name) preceded by either Mister or Miss.
social: There is a mandatory military service for Korean men of roughly 2 years that has to be completed before turning 30.
When drinking alcohol, look away from the table. It is considered to be impolite to drink while looking at someone.
When eating or drinking out, do not fill up your own glass. Instead let someone else pour your drink and then return the favor.
Always use two hands when receiving anything important such as a business card, this shows respect.
There is quite a high value placed on looks in South Korea.
Work dinners are very normal in Korea, these are seen as essential part of work. Missing them may be seen as disrespectful.

countries.name: Spain
summary: It is good to remember that almost the entity of Spain is Catholic to varying degrees.
People in Spain are taught from a young age to respect their elders, although not as strict as in some Asian countries it still good to be respectful to those of higher stage or older age then you.
The Spanish tend to be quite risk averse, often preferring to stay in a not great partnership for example to avoid risk.
organisational: Due to historical events, the Spanish tend to have a degree of distrust with regards to their own government. This can sometimes be seen in a general lack of reference for the law.
Related to the previous point, there is also a large grey economy, which concerns any labour done outside of the rules of law.
Almost everywhere in Spain, businesses will adhere to a siesta between 2 and 5 p.m. People will eat a warm lunch in this time and in some regions also take a quick cat nap.
Long-term job security is highly valued.
Punctuality is not very highly valued.
meetings: Meetings may be a bit less to the point, and of more a meandering nature, this can help with getting to know each other.
Team work is highly valued, so expect a lot of collaboration during meetings.
There may be a focus on more short term goals that show more immediate results.
social: Any small confrontation may escalate easily.
In many places in Spain, late night tapas are part of the food culture.
Physical contact is quite normal, so don't be scared if a colleague comes in for a hug after a work dinner out.

countries.name: United States of America
summary: American business culture is efficiency-oriented and money-driven.
Begin meetings with small talk on a light subject (weather, travel conditions, sports, e.g.).
After small talk, Americans get straight to business, even when the meetings start with a disagreement.
organisational: American business culture is efficiency-oriented and money-driven. The culture of the country is based on the belief that it is hard word that drives success, not status or age.
The hierarchical structure varies greatly depending on the region or company history. It is advised to learn the rank and titles of all the members you engage with inside an organization.
Final decisions are usually made quickly by a person with chief authority, but anyone is welcome to express their opinion in meetings or during the decision making process.
In general, it is not necessary to develop a personal relationship to establish a lasting and successful business relationship.
meetings: Punctuality and time management are fundamental values in US business culture, both in terms of time to start the meeting and time to terminate it.
In situations where you know you will be late, even by a few minutes, you should tell your American partner about your delay and offer to postpone the meeting.
During discussions, it is common to have small talk on a light subject (think weather, travel conditions, sports e.g) before talking business to create a comfortable environment.
After small talk, Americans get straight to the point, even when expressing disagreement.
Interaction, participation and concentration are important to prove your preparation and interest.
Americans are rather uncomfortable with silence, which is usually avoided in business meetings.
social: Generally, Americans like to laugh and enjoy talking with people with a sense of humor. Jokes are usually welcome.
Golf is a very popular sport, especially amongst business executives. Golf is normally a venue for business deals.
Unlike other cultures, it’s perfectly acceptable to refuse food or drink.
Business meetings that include lunch or dinner are not very common.

countries.name: United Kingdom
summary: The British are known for their “tongue-in-cheek” and ironic humour.
Business culture is less hierarchical, and managers keep a marginal power distance.
Requests are usually politely formulated, however managers’ suggestions should be followed as firm orders.
organisational: The business culture is less hierarchical than most countries in mainland Europe, as managers keep a marginal power distance.
Decisions are usually made from the top-down, nevertheless, they are not imposed abruptly but rather presented as guidelines or suggestions to follow.
The status of managers might be hard to detect as they try to have a consensus before directing others.
Directions are hinted at and instructions are usually polite requests such as “Perhaps we should try..”, however, managers’ suggestions are to be followed as though they were given as firm orders.
meetings: The British are known for their “tongue-in-cheek” and ironic humour, which they may use when doing business.
Make the appointment for your meeting a few days in advance, and indicate what its objectives are beforehand.
Punctuality and time management are extremely important in the UK. It is important to arrive on time or even slightly early.
Always give the impression that everything is well managed and under control. The British like to feel relaxed about business, no matter what the situation might be.
The British generally do not like to rush and are unlikely to commit to anything immediately, so don’t expect final decisions to be made during the first meetings.
Although meetings are often inconclusive, everyone who attended is expected to leave with a specific task.
social: A pub is often an intermediate place between work and socialization where colleagues can rest their professional pretences and bond in a non-hierarchical setting.
You may be invited to meetings at pub lunches or over dinner. In these settings, the host who offered the invitation pays the bill.

You should not be offended when people address you with a seemingly overfamiliar name such as “love”, “pet”, “mate”, or “darling” – these terms vary across the UK and they have no deep or hidden meaning.
Avoid explicit gestures and physical contact such as backslapping or hugging and maintain a sufficient distance as not to invade the personal space of anyone around you.
